newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins dip on freezing news but rise back.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins dip on freezing news but rise back.

text.p: Prices of Russian MinFin bonds initially fell on Friday some 0.5 points on news up to $7 million more bonds could be frozen, but dealers said prices bounced back later because the amount was not large and because a major depositary had informed the main traders about the move.

Russian police are preparing an order to freeze up to a nominal $7 million more of MinFin bonds, which have been stolen, banking sources told Reuters. In June, authorities froze $24.22 million of missing bonds.
"Prices started falling, but now they are rising back as the market must have realised the amount is not large. It is less than $24.2 million frozen earlier," Avtobank dealer Pavel Afanasyev said.
Other dealers said the market had reacted more calmly this time as Vneshtorgbank, the biggest MinFin depositary, had already advised some banks of the possibility of a freeze.
"Vneshtorgbank has informed all the main operators of the problem, giving their numbers," Eurobank dealer Olivier Coursault said. Eurobank had received this letter by fax on Friday.
"For the financial community, it is quite understandable some bonds can be stolen... but the situation is clear now as we know the numbers," he said.
